update.description: This pull request introduces the ability to set a default configuration file. The default configuration file will be saved when the user press "Save configuration". In the user wants to specify a different configuration file, the alternative "Save configuration as" will help.

content.raw:
Thanks! I think now what's left is to call `loadDefaultConfig` from `initApp`. What I tried was:

1. `ign gui -v 4`
1. Insert some widgets
1. Save configuration - the file is saved in the correct place
1. Close ign-gui
1. `ign gui -v 4` - an empty window is opened
content.html:
Thanks! I think now what's left is to call loadDefaultConfig from initApp. What I tried was:

  1. ign gui -v 4
  2. Insert some widgets
  3. Save configuration - the file is saved in the correct place
  4. Close ign-gui
  5. ign gui -v 4 - an empty window is opened

content.raw: To summarize, no error message when loading a default config file and doesn't exist. Otherwise, we show an error message (as it was happening before).  Sounds reasonable?

content.raw: oh yes :sweat_smile:
content.html: oh yes

content.raw: While **loading** from the default path, right?

content.raw: Looks good to me. This means we expect downstream projects to handle any problems while saving to their default path.

content.raw: Yes, the motivation was to avoid an error message when the default config file doesn't exist. There's another approach in 8ee21cc. Now, we only print an error message if the path is not the default path. What do you think?
content.html: Yes, the motivation was to avoid an error message when the default config file doesn't exist. There's another approach in 8ee21cc. Now, we only print an error message if the path is not the default path. What do you think?

update.description: This pull request introduces the ability to set a default configuration file. The default configuration file will be saved when the user press "Save configuration". In the user wants to specify a different configuration file, the alternative "Save configuration as" will help.
update.title: Save configuration

content.raw:
By "application" do you mean a downstream project using ign-gui as a library (such as gazebo) or a combination of plugins defined by someone who uses `ign gui` directly? 

For libraries, they can (and should) override this to their own path. 

For command line users, I imagine the use case as: "I always use the publisher and subscriber plugins arranged in a certain way, but I don't want to type `ign gui -c <custom file path>` every time, so I save this as my default configuration and every time I type `ign gui` that will be loaded." Do you think this is a valid use-case? I believe this is how RViz and RQT work.
content.html:
By "application" do you mean a downstream project using ign-gui as a library (such as gazebo) or a combination of plugins defined by someone who uses ign gui directly?

For libraries, they can (and should) override this to their own path.

For command line users, I imagine the use case as: "I always use the publisher and subscriber plugins arranged in a certain way, but I don't want to type ign gui -c <custom file path> every time, so I save this as my default configuration and every time I type ign gui that will be loaded." Do you think this is a valid use-case? I believe this is how RViz and RQT work.

content.raw: Is close not necessary here?

content.raw: Could we keep the message box? This is useful if the user tries to save a file under `/usr` for example.
content.html: Could we keep the message box? This is useful if the user tries to save a file under /usr for example.

content.raw: haha well that was misleading :laughing:
content.html: haha well that was misleading

content.raw: I guess that if we set `~/.ignition/gui/default.config` as the default location, this file won't exist until the user explicitly saves the configuration and we end up here. We could catch this special case and silently return false, since it is expected behavior. I still think we should print a message if another file fails to load though.
content.html: I guess that if we set ~/.ignition/gui/default.config as the default location, this file won't exist until the user explicitly saves the configuration and we end up here. We could catch this special case and silently return false, since it is expected behavior. I still think we should print a message if another file fails to load though.

content.raw: What's the motivation for removing this error message?
content.html: What's the motivation for removing this error message?

content.raw: How about we make this something like `~/.ignition/gui/default.config`
content.html: How about we make this something like ~/.ignition/gui/default.config

content.raw: Same here about mentioning that this is the full path including filename
content.html: Same here about mentioning that this is the full path including filename

content.raw: We could be more explicit and mention that the full path includes the filename. Otherwise someone could think this is only the directory path.
content.html: We could be more explicit and mention that the full path includes the filename. Otherwise someone could think this is only the directory path.
